018984.answer: i don't know what you're talking about i do understand the reference. it's a reference to one of my videos, 'shaving my piano.' a lot of people ask me serious logistical questions about actually shaving a piano, how to do it, how often to do it, what to use, etc... and my response is that it doesn't make sense. shaving a piano doesn't make sense, and is impossible. i did many other videos in 2014 in a similar format, acting out a simple yet illogical task, with physical and musical conviction. i think this was a fertile source of fun short videos, many of which caught on very well with viewers. i hope that makes sense

019014.question: how did you now you could smoke weed in california when it wasnt even legal there (for recreational use) in 2011? or is it bc u can technically smoke weed anywhere? or did u edit the lyrics later?
019014.answer: back at that time, california was known to be one of the most forward leaning states on marijuana laws. i think it was only medical by then, but they were one of the first. they were also known to be one of the most forward leaning on gay marriage, which is why the last line of the song got thrown in as well. as for the other states mentioned, there is no truth there whatsoever. alabama was known at the time to have some of the strictest marijuana laws of any state, perhaps still. the remainder of the states were chosen based on the fact that they are 3 syllables and sounded right in the song. over the years since the song was written, legalization of both marijuana and gay marriage have been sweeping the nation, and each time i think to myself 'oh no, i guess that california song probably won't make sense anymore.' but it was never entirely factual to begin with, so the additional inaccuracies make for a nice twist

019051.question: when i listen to "school" i think it's a deep statement on human nature, and more specifically, ignorance in a depressing way. school is a metaphor for knowledge in general. the lines "i don't wanna go to school, because i'm stupid, i don't want nobody tellin me what to do or how to get through this" to me seem like a statement on how people prefer to figure out life on their own way. they think they can wing it, make it up as they go, improvise. the next lines "i don't want nobody tellin me how to think, tellin me how to sing, tellin me how to do everything" really emphasize this point. but in the next lines, the true intentions behind the narrator's willful ignorance is revealed. "i don't wanna be afraid, of criminals, i don't wanna be afraid, of dangerous politicians" is the climax of the story. he doesn't want to expose himself to the harsh realities of the "real world", which could also be why the song uses the metaphor "school", since students are ofte n warned about said "real world". "i don't wanna be afraid of you, or of me, or the truth" further this point, because scariness is everywhere, and we all wish it wasn't like that, but we know deep inside of us that it is. the last lines, "said that girl made me feel blue, cause she told me I should stay in school, said that girl made me feel blue, don't go to school" is a nice closer, in which the narrator turns his nose to people telling him to "stay informed" or even perhaps "grow up", because all it does is make people sad. do you think this analysis is appropriate? or am i overthinking just a really catchy, danceable song? love your videos, ants just crawled out of my laptop.
019051.answer: your analysis is nice but it's not quite the way i meant it. my own analysis of this song is hiding somewhere (actually several places) throughout these questions pages, and is about equal in length to yours

019052.question: Did you follow your chart for your latest song exactly as written or did you change up some chords/notes/lyrics here and there with new bits?
019052.answer: the version i found from late 2013 was all set. i adhered to that version. that includes melody, chords, lyrics, exact tempo suggestion (112). details which were included in that version: the exact road map (except shortened the breaks after the choruses, and i let the end go on longer without fading). the exact chords in the pre-choruses. the answer riff over those chords in both pre-choruses (the organ riff, the one that's the same in both pre-choruses). the stray "in"s near the end. the modulation in the second chorus. details which were added during the recording (2017) the pre-intro noises all other auxiliary fills and instrumental riffs in response to lines (besides the main one in the late 2nd/3rd verses) vocal "yes i went there" small vocal prefixes before some of the states ("up in" "even in" etc) vocal "what the hell was i gonna say" near the end a slight melody variation in the second chorus, on "fool, ohh" which was originally the same as "rules, ohh" from the first chorus vocal harmonies

019053.question: in parts of your songs where you speak (not sing), are those originally in the chart or were they added when you're recording?
019053.answer: examples of vocal parts that were added during the recording and not previously written are: from 'we could just get high': the extra vocals near the end "we could get high, baby... book a flight, ... go to china baby, etc..." also the high "yeah" on the end. new canaan: before second verse- "there's something else i was gonna say." and all the outtro banter. also the spoken pre-intro tuesday: at the very end- "it'll be tuesday and that's ok" the road: added the word "so" at the end i can play: the line about the mall at the very end i'm crazy / it's raining: spoken lines in outtro "it's changing, i'm famous, i'm a baby, etc" it's gonna be alright: spoken lines in the intro, the whisper at the very end all u gotta do is: i think the spoken repeat of the last lyric at the very end i'm confused: spoken title line at the very end and surely many others

019084.question: I know you already have answered a few questions on here about defining music, and I like your thoughts on it. Really, it doesn't matter what the definition of music is. It has no clear definition, and yet it still exists, people make it and people listen to it and buy it. There's lots of different ways people have defined music.. some have given really simplified answers. Edgard Varese has one of the most famous definitions of music as being "organized sound." Frank Zappa said "a composer is a guy who goes around forcing his will on unsuspecting air molecules, often with the assistance of unsuspecting musicians." Barney Childs' definition is that "A piece of music is simply a chunk of time you are paying attention to with your ears." Others have given definitions that are more abstract, like Beethoven ("Music is the one incorporeal entrance into the higher world of knowledge which comprehends mankind but which mankind cannot comprehend"). You said "the onl y way i really know of to define it is by making some of it, or finding some of it to listen to. then you can go, "ah, that's music. i think"" .... But if music is in the eye (or ear) of the beholder... where does that leave the composer/creator/performer? If someone makes something that they personally intended to be music, then shouldn't it music rather or not you or I (or any other listener) interprets it as such?
019084.answer: it is your choice what to call music. you don't even have to decide. might be more fun that way anyway

019105.question: whats your song-picking system?
019105.answer: i'm randomizing from a long list of songs which includes songs where the writing is finished and where writing is not finished. whichever one i pick, i have to finish the writing, and record it. this is a system i started to use last year except this year i have added an extra twist which is that i tell myself that i technically don't have to release it, but i do have to finish it and record it. this is very important because it prevents me from getting cold feet about the selection, and helps me carry on and record it and not 'blame the selection.' this creates somewhat of a paradox because if i follow through on the recording, i'm gonna find a way to make it good, and will end up posting it in the end. but for some reason it really helps to at least pretend thst i'm not required to release it. this enables me to freely experiment on trying to make the best of what might seem like a weak selection. for example, when 'california' came up, my first reaction was 'oh no, not another weed song. people are gonna think all my songs are about weed' and i probably would have chickened out on the selection and then the entire credibility of the random system would collapse. but if i'm allowed to just 'try' recording it to see if i can make it good, it removes the pressure. and allows me to try making it the best i can make it, without stressing that it's the wrong selection. like i said, this strategy is a huge paradox in many ways but it seems to work

019167.question: two questions, if you don't mind :) 1. i want to do everything. i want to do lots of different stuff, i want to do maths, english, history, music, art, programming and loads of other shit but I can't do all of it. what do i do? 2. i am really lazy, and even though i have a lot of potential i waste it and don't put all of my effort into projects. how do i fix this? thank you bby
019167.answer: try to organize the things you want to do (this might not be entirely possible, but give it your best shot.) then start doing a series of very small projects. try to make up a schedule, maybe do 5 things a week, monday through friday, circling through the different categories. the short projects will be much easier to get done, and you will automatically start learning tricks and techniques very fast. your work will get better, and soon you will have everything it takes to move on to longer projects

019170.question: COuld you explain tritone substitution?
019170.answer: if you listen to this clip you might think you are just hearing a 2-5 in the key of C. you might think the bass is playing D, G (and to C next of course). it could be, and that would work normally. but if you listen closely the bass is actually playing D, Db (and to C next). in a 2-5, the G dominant 7th chord contains the notes B and F (a tritone). i guess some wise guy discovered that you can actually put Db in the bass instead of G, it still works. the tritone in the right hand (B and F) is the same in G7 as it is in Db7. what's more is, if you had a 13 in the G7 (E) so your right hand notes were F,B,E, that still works over Db, it becomes something like Db7#9 (F,B,E, same thing). that is actually the way it happens on the clip. another experiment you can do to better understand the situation: play 7th chords going thru the circle of 5ths: for example E7, A7, D7, G7, C7, F7, etc etc etc and don't include the 5th or the root in your right hand. so for E7, just play E in the bass and G# and D (which is all you really need to make it a 7th chord). and for A7 play just A in the bass and G and C# in the right hand, etc. and move through the 7th chords in this order. you will notice that the bass is moving thru the circle of fifths, but the tritone harmony in your right hand is actually just descending chromatically. nifty huh. so effectively, if you have 7th chords moving through the circle of 5ths like this, really if the bass player is feeling clever they can just move chromatically down. i hope that makes sense

019195.question: in an earlier question you mentioned that you had to go through quite a bit to keep you content on spotify, but you said 'it was a story for another time.' What is it that happened there?
019195.answer: basically you can't just upload your music to spotify. you have to pay somebody 'more important' who has the privilege to do it. some of these services charge a fee for every song, which would never work for me, because i plan on releasing a lot of songs. i found a service lets you do it unlimited for a yearly fee, and they deliver the song within a couple days (sometimes next day) to itunes and spotify. but unfortunately they refuse to send any songs that are less than 1 minute. so i actually had to sign up for a second service which allows short songs, but they take about 4 weeks to send it. so i am paying 2 different companies to upload my songs for me, depending on whether they are less or more than a minute. also, when it comes to putting my umbrella icon on my channel, i have mostly given up on that. they only take images from a database called "Rovi," and i have submitted my image to the database, but it never seems to go through. i read somewhere that Rovi basically only accepts who they want, and there's nothing i can do

019196.question: Why does nobody use the locrian scale?
019196.answer: once you start using the 'evil' notes, there is no point in sticking to a scale anymore. if you adhere strictly to locrian, it will only start to sound like one of the more normal modes, with a different root. for example if you start using only notes from B locrian, it will really probably just start to sound like C ionion or A aolean, etc etc

019282.question: "6.7.17 1:38 am" you mention a randomization system when asked about the saxophone in your new song. how is the randomization system responsible for the saxophone in the song, which the user asking the question commented that you don't use that often? is this the same randomization system you use for picking songs or is it some kind of instrument randomization system?
019282.answer: it's an instrument randomization system i came up with in 2015. the trick is, you pick a random instrument, and then you are responsible for finding where in the song it fits, and what to do on it. for example, you might pick something that seems all wrong for the song, and you might say "oh no, that's all wrong for this song." but if you start searching through the song, bar by bar, you will find just the right spot to put it. and then when listening to it, it sounds like a really fresh choice, and it fits the spot because you found where it fits, but the listener might think you went and found the instrument based on what would fit in that spot, but you actually picked the instrument first and then found the spot. life hack. turns out this is the only way i can get anything done now

019476.question: I love the lyric "this looks like a twelve-figure income town." Can you explain it in a bit more depth? Thanks
019476.answer: "6 figure income" means your yearly income (money) has 6 digits. so like 500,000 dollars a year is a "6 figure income." 5,000,000 dollars a year would be a 7 figure income. that lyric is from the song new canaan, which tells the story of an aimless exploratory trip to a random town accessible via the New York transit system. one of the most immediately notable traits of the town is that it seems to be a really rich town. a '6-figure income town' would be a town where people with a 6-figure income might live. 12-figures is surely an exaggeration, but it seemed to be the number that fit the best in the song at that time

019509.question: What's your daily schedule of song recording like?
019509.answer: currently it goes like this: pick a song randomly from the list, usually this would be on saturday if i finished the previous song on time. potentially have a panic attack about why i think i could never record that song, especially if it is old or crappy or seems wrong for me at the time. then i pull myself together and make the necessary changes to the song, or perhaps finish writing it becuase many of the songs are not fully written. then record the darn thing and hopefully have it done by saturday. that's about it. after a few weeks when i become more of an expert in this process, i would like to condense it down more, to have time to work on videos and many more things. similar to the way i was able to condense the vine production time in order to work on history of japan

Scientists know how different molecules/elements interact with eachother, how they will form bonds, react, release energy,etc. So if molecules behave in ways that are 100% predictible, do we really have free will?
019562.answer: there are some things that are divided into exactly 50/50 chance. consciousness exploits this 50% area

019563.question: I think it's a good thing to learn as much music theory as possible, because learning theory will give you different "tools" that you can chose to use (or not use) at your disposal. But one thing I've noticed with these theory-nerds (myself included) is that they'll over think things. Sometimes a simple ii-V-I sounds better than a tritone substitution. Sometimes a triad (or a two part harmony, or even a single note) works better than a fancy extended chord. I think I'm a much better player after years of studying and learning, but when I was first learning music I'd write songs much faster and more easily than I do now... Do you ever run into this probelm? Do you ever catch yourself over thinking things or trying to make songs more complex than they need to be?
019563.answer: not since i was much younger i think when you first start to learn how things work, it is normal to try to use the things you are learning in ways that emphasize the those particular things. but i think over time you will gravitate back toward the big picture. also it's important to remember that music can be described in as many different ways as you want, but the only fully accurate way to describe it is the way it sounds

019564.question: Do you usually write songs starting with the melody or starting with the harmony? In other words, do you come up with a melody and then come up with chord changes that compliment it? Or the other way around?
019564.answer: no no no, i do it both at the same time

019565.question: i understand that you don't want searching for better and better sounds all the time to get in your way of just writing and recording, but don't you want to transcend a lot of cultural elements that have no distinct purpose to you that you were born into? like approximating the way notes fit together in harmony by using the equal temperament tuning? i dont mean like retune your keyboards, but when talking about microtonal music, i usually tend to think of tuning chords to the harmonic series, rather than the piano. i just hope you actively do that when you can instead of using an easier way all the time to get more content finished. after all you do seem like quite the creativity purist. hell im sure you've thought about it tho. nevermind. you don't need to respond to this im just rambling cause i get triggered when you say no to microtonal music. ur right, splitting half notes in half again doesn't really make that much sense
019565.answer: ah, you are suggesting that i pursue the 'perfect' tuning, instead of using equal temperment tuning. this sounds like a righteous idea, but i have to tell you that i embarked on a viscious mission (in about january 2011 i believe) to get to the bottom of this situation. i set out to get a perfect tuning that at least worked in 1 key. after many hours (days? i don't remember) of experimentation, what i found surprised me. you actually can't do it. even to play within 1 key, you need to compromise. let me see if i can explain it: start by tuning a C chord properly (so that the E is a true harmony with C, and the G is a true 5th from C.) So let's get our F, that's gonna be a true 5th down from C, right? now A should be a pure major third above F, for sure. and B should surely be a pure major 3rd above G. now what should D be? you would assume that it would be a pure ninth from C (i.e. the frequency times 9 and then divided back down the octaves) which is good for the G chord also because it will be a 5th away from G. looks great, so now you've got C, D, E, F, G, A, B. but what you find next might come as a shock. D minor sounds like a nightmare. because D to A is supposed to be a 5th and now it is a very very wrong 5th. because you tuned your A to be a harmonically pure major 3rd away from F. no matter how you slice it, you inevitably run into the same argument where a 3rd needs to be a purely harmonic 3rd, but also needs to be a series of 5ths. i juggled the possibilities all around for at least a day, and i was completely stunned to find out that the essence of music, and specifically the way the "secondary" notes (let's say in a major key, the secondary notes are D, F, A, and also G, and the primary notes are C,E,G. that's right, G is both, the universe is a love paradox, get used to it) the secondary notes need equal tempered tuning to work right. there are surely many different ways to look at this and i made up the primary and secondary classifications for this example, but the point is that there will always be overlap. you will never have 2 exclusive sets of notes. it stems from the fact that the D note needs to be able to relate to G, but also needs to relate to the A, but the A also needs to relate to the F, and the F also definitely needs to relate to the C. now you might say "ok, tune them differently depending on what chords you're using." but that really doesn't work right, because music needs all these notes to coexist. you're not going to just expect that Dmin and Fmaj will never need to blend together with the A held over. or that Dmin and Gmaj will never need to blend together with the D held over. At the end of this mind exploding journey, i basically found that it seems to be summed up perfectly in 2 chords. Cmaj, and like any combination of D,F,A, and G perhaps with G in the bass. in that 'secondary' chord, all in one moment, (which is the 'less' stable of the 2 chords when they are used in a musical context) that chord encapsulates the dual nature of the way these harmonies are working. is the F in that chord supposed to relate mainly to the C? or is it supposed to relate to the D in a pure minor third? and similarly, is the D supposed to relate to the G? the answer is, all 3 of these relationships are supposed to hold together. but this is mathematically impossible to happen exactly. so the entire essence of that Dmin, or 5dom7(sus if you like?) whatever, 'secondary' chord, the entire essence of that chord is that it contains different relationships that have to all sound like they work and yet they could never all 3 work exactly. the chord needs compromise in order to work. perhaps that is why it feels like the secondary chord or the 'less stable' or the 'i'm just waiting to go back to C' chord. realizing this changed me, because i was always told that equal tempered tuning was mainly used as a compromise to play in all 12 keys. but what i realized is you actually need it just to play in 1 key. like, just to play a 1 and a 2min. just to play the most basic essence of a key and have it work with itself. it really made me appreciate that 'secondary' chord (Dmin, G, etc) the D to F and the D to G relationship on kind of an earth shattering spiritual level, it's like the damn thing has heartbreak built right in. what you think you are hearing is the d to f relationship and the d to g relationship and the f to c relationthip, etc, all at the same time, when really it could never be, at least not exactly. but it is close enough to feel it. basically ever since this experiment i have had a wildly new appreciation for how and why music works, on an even more 'human' level than i expected. and i never questioned equal tempered tuning again

019616.answer: there are many different variations of the commandments, and they have changed over time, but i did a lot of research into it in order to build the list i used. from what i found, it seemed that that commandment really (originally) meant that you're not supposed to want stuff that you are not supposed to have. the neighbor part seemed to have been added later, or only in some versions, if i remember correctly. at least that is the way it looked when i was doing the research. keep in mind this was a very long video and i don't exactly remember the details but i do remember that i did quite a bit of research just for that one screen that lasts maybe 1 second, and i was very careful to try to reflect the actual commandments as accurately as possible while still making it a rowdy fun time. when in doubt i tried to go for the older/original meaning, because there are so many different variations

019628.question: do you think it is possible to learn how to play a drum kit with little to no access to one? I've been a percussionist for years (marching band snare, djembe in church, etc.) but can't drum on an actual drum where i live. i desperately want to expand my abilities so I can just sit down at a set and play without feeling totally lost. i know i need a lot more limb independence and just straight up muscle memory to do that.... do you think it's possible to develop those any other way?
019628.answer: you can probably get pads that use a kick pedal, and you'll also need some regular drum pads, and then get like 3 or 4 snare stands, make sure they can go up high (so you can simulate the position of a high hat) and get a drum throne. and sticks which you surely already have. or if you've got a lot more money, you could get an electronic drum kit. you already have stick technique, but getting a kick pedal and some way to play a pad with it will be helpful because learning to use a kick pedal is it's own thing, just like learning to use the sticks

019700.question: I love your "harmonizing the weather lady" video and "the high class stuff" video. I want to try doing something similar (mimicking speech with music).. I think that would be a cool way to incorporate spoken word parts in songs.. but I can't seem to get the hang of it. Any tips? What was your process when writing the music to those videos?
019700.answer: start by deciding what the melody is. spoken language can be ambiguous, a lot of in between notes, a lot of bending slurs, a lot of totally ghost notes with no pitch. make a decision on what every note is. then go in and start having fun with the chords

019702.question: hallo! I wanted to ask you about I's, as I don't run into many other people who do not follow the capitalization guidelines just as they are given. I capitalize names as a measure of respect, and I consider I to be a name (your name for yourself when you are conveying yourself to someone else) but with how often I's turn up in text, it can feel self centered to capitalize it so often. do you think I should consider changing my policy?
019702.answer: there are many reasons why i like to leave the i lowercase. 1. it seems a bit more humble 2. it seems more casual 3. it is less pretentious 4. capital i looks exactly like a different letter 5. a lower case i is much more personal and has more personality because it has an eye

019721.question: I was going through the reality section and I found that after the history of japan video from last year you just suddenly stopped making any of the reality videos. was it because you were too focused on getting the other videos out, and eventually, HOTEWIG? or was it because of something else?
019721.answer: that's not quite how it went. instead of suddenly 'stopping' after history of japan, i suddenly Started after history of japan. the reality page never existed before that. after releasing history of japan i thought it would be a good chance to do what i've wanted to do for years, which is actually go through those thousands of hours of journals and edit them into something watchable, that shows what my life is like. it took about 3 months of solid work (feb-may, 2016) to collect and edit all those clips and make videos out of them. all other projects were put on hold in order to do those reality videos. everyone thought i was dead. finally i rushed through the last 2 years of the project and skipped out on huge sections of time, just to finish it around may 2016, and finally move on to more exciting newer content. by that time, there were also 3 new months of journals, mostly talking about editing journals of course. but i decided to save that for the next update, whenever i get a chance to put my career on hold again for 3 months. which is ironically what everyone thinks i'm always doing, because i can't make everyone's favorite type of content at the same time. for example, now i am doing songs every week. which is great news for all the people who wanted me to do songs while i was trying to do the reality videos. but unfortunately it is bad news for you. either way it is bad news for me, because i want all of it to be done immediately. i hope that makes sense

019736.question: what do you think of this idea for more time for you to do songs?
019736.answer: given the amount of songs to do, i think it's important to put them out every week. what's more is, given the huge amount of other things to do (such as videos, and much more) it is also important to condense the song production time to much less than a week, to have sufficient time to get anything else done. but i am a long way from making this a reality. i don't really know what to do. one of my best days recently was last monday when i divided up the day between working on a new video, collecting clips for the next reality update, collecting notes for a notes update, managing various social media platforms, writing tweets, answering emails, ... it was a wonderfully well rounded and productive day. but as a result, that set me back a day on the song schedule and the later part of the week was big panic time and i barely managed to finish the song on time. this week will be worse, and there will be absolutely no time for anything except the song. i don't really know what i'm going to do

019737.question: Which one of these is the most correct interpretation of your creative process for making long videos? 1. research - narration - vocal melodies - chords - graphics 2. research - narration - chords - vocal melodies - graphics 3. research - narration - graphics - chords - vocal melodies 4. Just feel it, man. Fuck the process. 5. Listen to more records, close the Real Book.
019737.answer: it's more like write/research/write (including writing the exact notes and chords of all the parts with singing).... phase 2 is make a plan for how to execute the thing and gather all the elements needed.... then record a temp narration with proper timing including any singing... then build the actual visuals over that.... then record the final narration... re-allign the timing of the graphics to fit the new narration.... record the final music and vocals for the parts with singing.... then finally do all the other instrumental music and sounds that fills the rest of the video.... then start doing troubleshooting lists and fixing everything on the list until you have smaller and smaller lists until the things to fix are so small that you don't care

019745.question: What hurdles did you have to jump to get "got to know what's going on" done as quick as possible. Or really, what made it hard?
019745.answer: writing a full song and recording it is a tight squeeze in a week. it was tough with movie star, but for movie star i was able to copy and paste a lot of the vocals. i normally have a rule against doing that, but i was up against the clock so a lot of those title lines (especially the background harmonies) are just copied and pasted. "got to know what's going on" has a lot more lyrics with harmonies, and a lot more Different lyrics with harmonies. so all those parts in the chorus with all those harmonies have different lyrics. also i spent monday of last week working on other projects (videos, reality updates, notes updates) which was very important because i need to get to those projects but it really screwed up the week for the song. i was about 3 days behind schedule. so this week is even more impossible. i think it's impossible this week. i need to do videos anyway. i need to do 10 different things at the same time. i need to re evaluate my life, or find people to help me somehow, even though i feel like i'm the only one who really knows how to do things the way i want. i am re evaluating my life

019755.question: Where do you get the impression that "microtonality is usually associated with an artificially constructed 24 tone chromatic scale"... I thought microtonality just meant dividing the traditional 12-tone chromatic scale into more than 12 tones.. Can't you divide an octave into 13 evenly spaced intervals, or into 999999999 ka-zillion equally spaced intervals and have that be considered microtonal? I've never heard of microtonality as strictly referring to dividing the the 12 semitones in half... Just curious.
019755.answer: whenever i hear people talk about microtonality they are usually talking about a 24 tone scale, or at the very least, an evenly divided scale other than 12. if you are using freedom of pitch like a trombone or voice or pitch bend wheel, i don't really consider that any kind of scale. i just consider that freedom of pitch, free pitch, or using any pitch you want, etc

019757.question: Did anything come out of that paramount TV series thing?

019770.question: 6.20.17 7:03 pm you answered "i'm not sure what you mean". this is your usual answer whenever someone refers to your music as "joke" music. i don't think anyone thinks it in the negative sense, but your music certainly exudes a humorous, joking feel. you can't be serious when you say that you don't understand that, right? comparing art is usually pointless, but for example, would you not say that Radiohead's music (for example) has a lot more serious tone and message compared to your music? with lyrics like "i'm a movie star" you can't expect people to not think that you're aiming for humor. all that said, your stuff is great, i just wanted to ask you why you refuse to accept your musical style with specific wording and just evade all attempts at classification

019801.question: Do you have any recurring dreams? If so, what are they?
019801.answer: the main one is that i can fly, but not the real way. like only a tiny bit. like the point of the dream is that it's normal, i can't really fly, but if i just jump and press down on the air fast, repeatedly, i can get a tiny bit higher off the ground. kind of like swimming with both hands at he same time, while jumping. the dream is never about realizing i can do that, i already knew. the realization is that if i just keep doing it, i can keep going higher and actually get as high as i want, reasonably fast, i just have to do it a little bit at a time. i've been having this dream all my life. as time goes by i'm noticing more and more ways that my life resembles this dream

019807.question: why did you feel like a piece of garbage in 2007?
019807.answer: i'm not sure. in fact i don't know if i did. and it certainly wasn't for the whole year. just a particular page which was randomly selected during a 2015 vine writing session, which looked like many of the things you might find in the notebook section, except it was terrible. not good, no value, no creativity, and clearly very unhappy. not good. so the vine i wrote to reflect that was "hello, i'm a piece of garbage". a few random picks later i randomly happened upon another page, from the next day, in 2007. total coincidence. this page was also garbage, in a similar fasion. i was puzzled for a moment because the vine-writing system i was using was supposed to take me to random places in the journals but it just brought me to the exact same situation twice in a row. then i realized the best option was to write a repeat of the same vine, "oh hi, thanks for checking in, i'm still a piece of garbage." i hope that makes sense. so those vines are fictional, written in 2015, but reflecting what seems to be depicted on 2 randomly selected journal pages (both coincidentally from 2 consecutive days during the summer of 2007).

019819.question: From what I've gathered from your answers on here, you get a lot of criticism and requests and it seems to get to you. Even with well intentioned questions that say something like 'hey, I think you may be overworking, so remember to take care of yourself' you respond to in a very prickly way. I can never know what you go through, and I have no doubt it must be endlessly frustrating, but perhaps it's time to try to pay less attention to people being pushy (if you haven't). You probably also need to realise like some people (e.g. the example above) are only inquiring in good faith, and you should try not to take your frustrations out on them.
019819.answer: normally i'm fine but every once in a while i snap after being pulled in every direction 100s of times. can you imagine, in addition to people always thinking i'm neglecting everything, some people think i work too fast, and wonder why i work so hard. your question included, because you probably don't realize the quantity of contradictary requests, demands etc, which i regularly ignore in a calm fashion

019822.question: re: wings songs, i heard let em in yesterday and didn't know who wings were, but i was like Wow this is so mccartneyish, and then i googled it. but yeah i think let em in is quite a neat song, maybe a bit repetitive but pretty funky. so what do you think of let em in?
019822.answer: i think it's great. i've probably never heard past the first couple minutes. paul has a habbit of sending a 2 minute song around in circles when it might not need to. one thing i find particularly valuable is the elongated hang at the end of the chorus. he hits a Fmaj7 chord (somg is in Bb) in the midst of that which is a super neat twist on what otherwise might be accomplished using C7. also what i think is valuable about that song is that the verse gets away with making nothing sound like something. the doorbell's ringing, get the door! that's all!!! not even any rhymes in the verse!! that's one thing that paul has done many times for me, is remind me that you can get away with Anything as long as you can convince yourself you're having fun

019866.question: the font you use in your videos comes in all sorts of weights (http://i.imgur.com/R1j4QeM.png), do you ever plan on using the other ones?
019866.answer: i used to worry about different fonts for everything, but that became not only a waste of time, but also distracting from a viewing standpoint. i ultimately made a decision to actually use the default font for everything. it gave me a lot of creative clarity, and greater efficiency. i learned it's better to focus on your strong points, and don't worry about things that are not your strong points. i don't make my own fonts, and i don't have access to a large font libary, so this would not be a strong point. by religiously using the default font only, i found that i could instantly put all my focus on things that are my strong points -- positioning, angles, motion, and timing, and of course the content of the text

019868.question: how do you choose what key to put a song in?

019956.question: Do any intervals really have dissonance or consonance, or have we just been conditioned to think of certain harmonies that way through hundreds of years of repition? Same as a majority of music (at least western music) being in 4/4 time.. is there something special about 4/4 that has made it become "standard"?
019956.answer: the good intervals sync up with each other mathematically. the wave forms sync up. it's kind of like if one person is clapping 150% faster than another person. their claps will sync up in time, 2s are very powerful. that's because 2 is a low number, and almost anything can work in 2s. breathing (in, out) walking (left right). the next number is 3, which is also low, and very simple, and that is a prominent number in musical rhythms as well. 4 is just 2 2s. so when something is in 4, it's just 2s. 2 groups of 2. and then 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 (2 bars.) and then 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 (4 bars.) that's why music works so well in 4, 8, and 16 bar sections. you're just hearing 2s in 2s in 2s etc

019978.question: Do you feel like the line "damn it seems like writing songs is a lot like being in prison and I realize that the only one who put me there is me" from the song song applies to your post-hotewig life? Cause it seems you're pushing yourself to make all this crazy new content at a crazy rate and it's like you're putting yourself back in prison for no other reason than "i wanna do this song or that video asap"
019978.answer: that relates more to songwriting. i have now figured out a cornucopia of different tricks and methods for songwriting, and no longer feel blocked in that regard most people still don't even think i am making any content. they always think i've 'stopped.' this is because it is impossible to make content instantly, especially if it is anything of a reasonable size. so therefore i need to hustle like crazy just to keep things coming out at a somewhat reasonable rate

019979.question: i find your goals a bit mysterious. basically, from what you let on here, you want to create as much as possible before you die. just constant creation of your stuff. but, interestingly, you even consider other types of creation to be obstacles in the way of your other creations. so you say things like "i'd make more of X but then I have to make less of Y". what are your motives here exactly? you do realize you've already made 10 albums worth of stuff? do you wanna be Zappa? I guess Zappa is good. do you have more mainstream aspirations like releasing albums, touring, interviews? i think it wouldn't be unwise to take some time to try to work on those things. expanding your influence, expanding your experience. doing this and then doing that other thing. your music and work would probably benefit from something like that.
019979.answer: if you do more of one thing, have to do less of the other things because you are busy making the first thing. it's like if you want to make 10 cakes and 10 pies. you might be able to make 15 cakes instead, but maybe you can only make 5 pies, because you were busy making cakes instead. this rule does not apply if you have infinite time, or if you can somehow pause time. but i have not figured out a way to do that yet unfortunately not really i don't think songs need to be in groups. from what i can tell, it is usually the singles that are mainstream, not the albums i prefer to do questions here everything seems to be going great
